p: There are many examples of outbreaks of PN due to hexacarbon solvents (such as n-hexane and methyl-n-butyl-kenone), first observed in Japan in the 1960’s then in Europe and the US. Hexacarbon exposure leads to subacute-chronic dying-back PN, sometimes with giant axons and demyelinating signs on nerve biopsy (Fig. 4) [ 76]. These solvents were especially used in shoe-making and the printing industry. Another common cause of hexacarbon PN is the deliberate inhalation of the vapors of lacquers or glue (“ glue- sniffing”) [ 77].
